data.title: Add Feature: Preserve line position after editor:delete-line
AtomIDE does not recover well after force-close
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

Atom IDE recovers poorly when it's forced-closed after encountering a performance issue.  I searched for this issue but don't see it, although maybe it's worded differently.
### Steps to Reproduce
1.  Cause AtomIDE to hang.  To do this, create a file with very long lines that must be syntax-colored.  In most operating systems a dialog prompt will appear to "force close" the app.
2.  Force close Atom when prompted by the OS.
3.  Wait several seconds for any OS logging/recovery.
4.  Re-launch Atom.
5.  Atom re-opens the same files already open during the previous session.  The same long-lines must syntax-colored and Atom will hang again, repeating this entire cycle.

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]
It seems like a good idea to remember the documents that were open last.  However that backfires in this case.  Might as well detect a crash and clear the previous documents list to avoid an infinite loop of use-cases.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]
AtomIDE re-opens the same files that were open before hanging and force-closed, and ends up the same cycle.
### Versions

Atom    : 1.9.9
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0

apm  1.10.0
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.12
git 2.7.4

data.title: Bad Performance related to syntax coloring
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

When commenting long HTML lines, the editor hangs if the comment is authored in a natural way.  There is a workaround that can avoid the editor hang.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Create an HTML document with multiple long lines of HTML code.  For example, create a script tag and place the contents of a large file into it.  Then create a second tag with the contents of another file.  NOTE:  you may need more HTML contents to reproduce this issue, if so simply create the code.
2. Preprend an HTML comment to the first script tag, i.e. "<!--".  The code below will be re-colored as a comment.
3. Append "-->" to the closing script tag.  The editor will hang while re-coloring the syntax.

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]
Just use the previously known coloration when closing the comment.  Why re-process?

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]
Editor hangs while re-coloring.
### Workaround

When commenting long lines with an HTML comment, add the closing token first, then add the opening token.  No hanging occurs.
- NOTE:  there's no reason to think this doesn't happen with long JavaScript lines commented with /\* ... */.  Although unverified there's reason to suspect this could be a general problem for any programming language with multi-line comments in AtomIDE.
### Versions

Atom    : 1.9.9
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0

apm  1.10.0
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.12
git 2.7.4

data.title: Remove unused variables (obvious ones)
data.body:
This is a split from #12189 to reduce cognitive load. All changes should be obvious enough to convince within 30 seconds for any given change that it is ok to remove/change.

Unlike #12189, this does not require up to date CoffeeScript.

data.title: Leaving context menu open causes "editor not responding" window to open
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

If the context menu is left open for about 30s or so the "editor not responding" window pops up. After the "Keep waiting" button is clicked, there doesn't appear to be any further problems.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open a text file.
2. Right click and hover the mouse over the context menu
3. wait about 30s

**Expected behavior:** the editor/context menu remain available to use.

**Actual behavior:** "editor not responding" window popped up.
### Versions

Atom    : 1.10.2
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0

Ubuntu 16.04 LTS
kernel version: 4.4.0-38-generic

data.title: Update coffee-script to 1.11.0
data.body:
With help from @50Wliu in #12189 we've managed to get Atom's CoffeeScript files (also in bundled packages) forward-compatible with [CoffeeScript >=1.9.0](http://coffeescript.org/#1.9.0): > Changed strategy for the generation of internal compiler variable names. Note that this means that @example function parameters are no longer available as naked example variables within the function body. This has only one major drawback - community packages which still use the old style need to be updated in a similar fashion, so before making a major release, we should give enough time for package developers to ensure their packages work with the new version. Most of the time it is fixable by adding a `@` in front of the parameter variable name. Inevitably this will also introduce issues like "the new version broke package xyz".
If you are a package developer, use coffeelint already and want a somewhat convenient way to check your coffeescript project for that specific error, expand me. For Atom packages I used [coffeescope2](https://github.com/za-creature/coffeescope) with following configuration (add into `coffeelint.json`). ``` json "check_scope": { "module": "coffeescope2", "level": "warn", "environments": ["es5", "es6", "browser", "node", "jasmine"], "globals": { "atom": true, "afterEach": true, "beforeEach": true, "describe": true, "fdescribe": true, "xdescribe": true, "expect": true, "it": true, "fit": true, "xit": true, "jasmine": true, "runs": true, "spyOn": true, "waitsFor": true, "waitsForPromise": true, "indexedDB": true }, "overwrite": false, "shadow": false, "shadow_builtins": false, "shadow_exceptions": ["err", "next"], "undefined": true, "hoist_local": true, "hoist_parent": true, "unused_variables": false, "unused_arguments": false, "unused_classes": true } ``` Then run: ``` npm install npm install coffeescope2 node_modules/.bin/coffeelint . ``` ![screen shot 2016-09-26 at 18 23 37](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1017132/18840213/77bda71e-8416-11e6-8a5b-f43e6e1c3cac.png) Undefined identifier is potentially the problematic spot you will want to fix. In my case the following change was enough: https://github.com/atom/open-on-github/commit/1f19165cadec324a6f300e371ebfe3b72898e1fd After that it is up to you whether you want to keep using coffeescope2 or not, but it should help avoiding the most common issue that comes with this CoffeeScript update. Using coffeescope2 after this procedure is completely optional. **One extra note as I see people copying this configuration to their projects. Some of very useful functionality of coffeescope2 has been disabled in this configuration, so that we could focus on fixing the current issue. You are missing out on quite a bit (namely detection of unused variables, variable overwriting and shadowing), you might want to take a look at it by enabling the flags in configuration.**
Closes #9739

Not sure if it's any malformed JS file or just this one but I have a file that i can reproduce with every time. ### Steps to Reproduce 1. create a file with these contents https://gist.github.com/thedaniel/0e95c39c4b1e5d688be17a5ba76dd80d 2. run editor:auto-indent 3. cry **Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen] file would be indented, or the editor would try and fail to indent and i'd be able to continue editing **Actual behavior:** [What actually happened] ### Versions Atom : 1.10.2 Electron: 0.37.8 Chrome : 49.0.2623.75 Node : 5.10.0

data.title: GitHub Desktop for Windows launches old version of Atom
data.body:
When I launch Atom Editor using the "Atom" button in GitHub Desktop, it launches an old version (1.9.9) rather than the currently installed one (1.10.2).
When I launch it any other way (like from Start Menu), then it launches the current version.

Is there a way for me to remove previous versions or update GitHub Desktop to point to the current version?

I could not find the GitHub Desktop repo to post this issue.
I thought it still could apply here because it involves removing old versions of Atom Editor.
### Description

GitHub Desktop launches an old version of Atom
### Steps to Reproduce

(With multiple versions of Atom installed)
1. Open GitHub Desktop
2. Click "Atom" button in top right corner

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]

Launch current version of Atom installed.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]

Launches old version of Atom (1.9.9) instead of current (1.10.2)
### Versions
- Atom 1.9.9
- Atom 1.10.2
- GitHub Desktop 3.3.0.0
- Windows 10 Home 64 bit

data.title: Bad Performance related to Coloration and Undo buffer
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

Pasting a long line of minified JavaScript into an HTML doc causes slow performance.  This appears to be due to the coloration feature, and although it's barely acceptable I believe there are other bug reports related to that.

Once the long line is pasted poor performance is easy to encounter again.  Just highlight the newly pasted lines, and delete them.  I don't know for sure this is related to the architecture and/or implementation of the undo buffer, but that seems like a reasonable place to start.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open/create an HTML document.
2. Create an empty script tag for text/javascript in the HTML doc.
3. Paste the minified jquery JS into the script tag, the contents at https://code.jquery.com/jquery-3.1.1.slim.min.js
4.  Wait -- (repeatedly) clear any prompts that may appear due to system hanging.
5.  Highlight the newly pasted lines.
6.  Press backspace/delete.
7.  IDE hangs.

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]
Delete the highlighted lines and return control to the user.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]
IDE hangs.

*\* Workaround **
Follow step 4 above.
### Versions

Atom    : 1.9.9
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0

apm  1.10.0
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.12
git 2.7.4

data.title: Variable scope color

### Description

Variable should have different  color in its scope
**example**
`

```
function example() {

    newVar.push('a'); // white color
}
newVar.push('b'); // red color because variable cannot access OR show red underline
```

`

data.title: Support touch interfaces
data.body:
### Description

Atom currently doesn't support touch interfaces to scroll the editor (though the sidebar scrolls with touch just fine). This probably extends to "precision touchpad" or "natural" scrolling methods as well, which work similarly.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Touch the screen and wiggle your finger a bit.
2. Observe the dead, unfeeling stillness of the code on your screen.
3. Weep.
### Versions

Atom 1.10.2, Windows Version 10.0.14393 Build 14393

data.title: Character `[ ` unusable in text, keymap fr_BE, because of Keybinding
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

Hi, in Atom-core, when I write text (such as pseudo code or markdown), I can't have access to the `[` character, because the keybinding is defined as such : 

| Keystroke | Command | Source | Selector |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| ctrl-[ | editor:outdent-selected-rows | Core | atom-workspace atom-text-editor:not([mini]) |

Here is the _Belgian Keyboard Layout_ 
![belgian keyboard layout](http://www.keysourcechina.com/img/img/img/20117122320473499.jpg)

As you can see, the `[` character in on level 3 on Belgian layout, where on English, it's on the first level. As we need `ctrl-alt` (or `alt-gr`) to write ´[´, nothing can happen because of the keybinding in the same time. This happens on Windows and it might happen on Linux too. I am not sure on macOS / OS X, however.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Change keyboard layout to Belgian (`fr_BE`)
2. Try to use `[` in ATOM

**Expected behavior:** Get `[`.

**Actual behavior:** Nothing happens.
### Versions

```
Atom: 1.10.2
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome: 49.0.2623.75
Node: 5.10.0
```

On Windows 10.

Greetings !

data.title: Cannot install packages / Win 10
data.body:
Atom 1.8.0, Windows 10

Note: the Users/user/.atom/packages folder exists, is writable, and contains a previously installed package.
1. open settings
2. go to Install
3. type any name, press ENTER
4. the following error appears:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/588573/18816308/69faa7b6-834f-11e6-927c-e60d06168902.png)

The error in the Dev console:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/588573/18816327/17b8322e-8350-11e6-8eb0-d1b8decc62fe.png)

It may relate to the very first error in the Dev console:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/588573/18816333/417bc9fe-8350-11e6-9b98-03d2d2dd3d84.png)

data.title: Scrolling down document when no lines left
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [Yes] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [Yes] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [No] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [Yes] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [Yes] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [Yes] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

[Description of the bug or feature]
I can scroll document down even if it has no lines left with data. There's a lower bound so I can't doing this continuously. The frame between last  line of data and actual 'lower bound' is about 25 lines. It feels like invisible 'something'.

I've never experienced that before updating to macOS Sierra, but not sure if it started right after updating thus I can't be sure that updating to Sierra causes that issue.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. [Open any file with any number of lines]
2. [Make sure you have n lines of code and (n + ~25) enables scrolling]
3. [See the issue]

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]
I want editor to show lines exactly document has and no more.
**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]
I
### Versions

Atom    : 1.10.2
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0
![atom_issue](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6034290/18814543/fe8c6864-831e-11e6-9a84-f5761266a796.gif)
![screen shot 2016-09-25 at 12 30 30 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6034290/18814544/fe95b3b0-831e-11e6-970c-795a5c9a46aa.png)

data.title: Keymap: toggleLineCommentsInSelection  small improvement
data.body:
Really small UX improvement for toggleLineCommentsInSelection: after commenting/uncommenting text, cursor will move down, so you can continue commenting the following line.

Inspired by PyCharm

data.title: Hidden title-bar
data.body:
This PR is similar to https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/10208 (Hide title bar on OS X) and contiues from https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/11790. It replaces the current "Use Custom Title Bar" checkbox with a "Title Bar" dropdown. It has the following options:
- `native` (default)
- `custom` adapts to themes
- `hidden` **New**! Only the traffic lights are shown

![screen shot 2016-10-15 at 7 40 34 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/378023/19409487/51d840c4-930f-11e6-98e8-6cefd0a21df2.png)
### Native

![screen shot 2016-10-15 at 7 34 06 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/378023/19409427/64c5ac04-930e-11e6-8dda-ed7775214bde.png)
### Custom

![screen shot 2016-10-15 at 7 32 23 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/378023/19409431/746936c6-930e-11e6-9408-3d80e4806ee8.png)
### Hidden (new)

![title-bar-custom](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/378023/18807178/79a7a210-827b-11e6-8f96-6b2a9bf28b02.png)
## Benefits:

Be able to hide the title bar leaves more room for the editor and looks less cluttered. Also a package like the tool-bar could use the title bar's place instead.

![title-bar-custom 2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/378023/18807177/79a71afc-827b-11e6-8bc9-68ec69338e59.png)
## Concerns:

When the tree-view is hidden, a vertical bar is shown to make sure the traffic lights don't overlap anything and that there is an area where the window can be dragged.

![screen shot 2016-10-25 at 7 08 22 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/378023/19682048/d01f77a2-9ae6-11e6-8ec1-b9d51e64bf84.png)
## Affected packages:
- [ ] tool-bar (nothing major, but could still use some tweaks like centering the icons when it's on the left and tree-view is hidden.

/cc @brumm

data.body:

TypeError: Cannot read property 'Symbol(Symbol.iterator)' of undefined

    at ApplicationDelegate.module.exports.ApplicationDelegate.getCurrentWindow (/usr/lib/atom/src/application-delegate.js:33:21)
    at AtomEnvironment.module.exports.AtomEnvironment.getCurrentWindow (/usr/lib/atom/src/atom-environment.js:565:39)

    at /usr/lib/atom/src/window-event-handler.js:3:61
```
### Commands

  2x -2:42.1.0 core:backspace (atom-text-editor.editor.is-focused)

```

data.title: Feature request: Collapse functions/blocks
data.body:
Hi,

I extensively use the collapse function of the editor. When opening a source file, however, the editor expands all collapsed functions/blocks. Is there a way for the editor to remember what was collapsed the last time? Or failing that, could it open any file with all functions collapsed? Or provide a shortcut/button to do the same?

Every time I open a file I spend about a minute collapsing all functions that are of no interest to me at the time...

Thanks

viktak

data.title: Make main-process/main.js as minimal as possible
data.body:
In order to test changes to main.js, we need to rebuild the application. For this reason, it makes sense to do as little work as possible here. In this PR, we change main to just determine the resourcePath, then use that path to require a start function which can be iterated on in dev mode.

This PR is a prerequisite to much larger changes we plan to make to the main process code. It will make these changes much easier to test as we develop them.

:pear:ed with @maxbrunsfeld

data.title: Use app 'activate' event instead of defunct 'activate-with-no-open-windows'
data.body:
This restores the ability to open a Window by single-clicking the dock icon on macOS.

🍐 ed with @maxbrunsfeld 

Closes https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/12728

data.title: Make it easier to define user key bindings
data.body:
1. User key bindings now take precedence over package key bindings regardless of their selector specificity.
2. We now throw errors if key binding files contain duplicate keys. This was an easy error to make because it's easy to think of these CSON files as working like style sheets, rather than JSON objects.

Closes https://github.com/atom/atom-keymap/issues/110

🍐  w/ @nathansobo

data.title: Don't interleave package serialization with package deactivations
data.body:
This PR changes our approach to package deactivation on window teardown. Previously, we called `serialize` on each package during `deactivatePackages`, which was called when destroying the package manager. Now, we rely on `PackageManager.serialize` being called as a result of saving window state, which always happens before unloading the window.

We needed to change our window IPC code to ensure that all code paths leading to a window reload gave the window a chance to serialize its state. We also did a bit of cleanup while we were in there.

🍐 ed with @maxbrunsfeld 
/cc @matthewwithanm
